Description: Latinos are a dynamic, diverse population. But cancer threatens the future health of our population. The number of Latino cancer cases are expected to rise 142% in coming years, and Latinos suffer disparities in liver, stomach, and cervical cancer incidence, and worse outcomes in other cancer types. These disparities are driven by structural inequities—from a lack of healthcare access to unreliable housing—that have been built into governmental laws, economic policies, school systems, neighborhoods, businesses, research, and healthcare. Also, the pipeline of Latino healthcare workers and leaders does not reflect national population demographics. We need to create and translate research advancements into clinical best practices, system changes, effective community interventions, professional training programs, and advocacy actions to address Latino health inequities and prevent their resulting cancer disparities, thus saving lives.
SearchResultBody: ME23. Exploring Latino Cancer Health Disparities with a Focus on Prevention and Community Intervention
Title: Exploring Latino Cancer Health Disparities with a Focus on Prevention and Community Intervention
